title: It's all in the HIPS | Frontside Boardslides

transcript.text: Spiritual enlightenment, death of ego, a
pursuit as old as humanity itself. And
snowboarders are no different. And how
they chase it is with the front side
board slide. Ask any border around and
they'll tell you nothing will humble you
faster or harder than trying to get a
grasp of this trick. It is a full
spiritual, physical, multi-year journey
to get landing in that will try to break
you and reform you. But I don't really
believe in any of that stuff. So in this
video, I'm going to show you how to do
this trick in a safe, effective way. So
hopefully you can lace it right away and
don't need to go and complete a complete
spiritual journey in order to land it.
First, let's break down the two most
common slams and why they happen because
it'll give us a lot of super necessary
context for rest of this video. So here,
both these boys, they're doing slightly
different things, but they're making the
same mistake. And that's twofold. First,
they're leaned over, jumping towards the
feature itself. This is going to give
them a lot of sideways momentum. So once
they are on the feature, their weight is
getting shifted towards her back foot.
And then they combine that with
something else that causes the edge
catch. And that's too much upper body
rotation for the bend in the legs. When
you start rotating your upper body, it's
going to shift your weight more and more
towards your back heel. And that's
exactly what's happening here. They're
on the rail. They're unbalanced, not
locked in. And then as they slide across
it, their weight's going and pulling
their weight over to that back heel.
That's adding a lot of torsional flex in
the snowboard, shifting the weight back,
and it results in a heel catch. What's
really brutal, like look at these slams.
It's just one of those things you can't
have happen. The other slam is the

upper body is too bent forward for the
hinge in the hips, making it so your
center of balance isn't stacked over
that board. on a down rail. Even if you
land centered, if you're not in position
that can handle the change in gforce,
it's not flexible enough, you're going
to slip out. So, in this instance,
there's a few things that cause this to

hyperextending her legs, jumping
upwards. We don't really want to be
elongating herself, jumping herselves
up, because now she has to go and crunch
herself down. And because she's
crunching herself down into this
position, it's causing her to go and
lean forward. And there's one more thing
here that's the main cause of this and
that's this two- centered stance. A
front side board side's a little bit

it over to your front foot so you can go
and pull out your back foot. But if we
leave off our front foot off the jump,
we'll get this like two-footed jump
sensation and we won't be able to get
far enough on the rail to just use base
principles to counter rotate into it.
And that's going to make it so you're
crunching down trying to reposition. And
if we have any inconsistency like that,
it's going to lead to a slip out. Prime
example of messing up the takeoff here.
The dude's weights completely leaned
towards the rail. So when he jumps up,
his legs are going to push him. That's

far away from his upper body. And then
as he hits a rail, he has a lot of

And that's why it's so important to
